headline: The real life of Bryan Mbeumo - from piano and chess to Manchester United and dreaming big
body: Bryan Mbuemo's Manchester United initiation song might sound a little different.
Footballers often integrate themselves into their new surroundings by singing a song, Mbuemo may well be playing piano.

The United new boy is a keen pianist and might even greet his new team-mates with a tune or two as he joins them in America for their pre-season tour having completed his £65million transfer this week.
Mbeumo is a keen pianist having taught himself using YouTube videos. Brentford even put a piano at the training ground to allow him to practice.
"I discovered it a few years ago," he said in his first interview as a United player, speaking to club media. "A friend of mine was playing in front of me and was amazing so I wanted to try."

United will be hoping to get their own tune out of him to help them rebuild and regroup after a desperate campaign last term. The Reds moved to bring in Matheus Cunha after activating his £62.5m release clause and Mbeumo has now followed as Ruben Amorim revamps his attack.

Cunha scored 15 top-flight goals last season while Mbeumo contributed 20. The Cameroon international has significantly improved his cutting edge in front of goal over the last two seasons, in keeping with a man who always wants to improve.

While at Brentford he teamed up with a posture specialist and a home-visiting physio as well as a personal chef. He worked hard to improve his finishing with club coaches and is part of Brentford's leadership group.
He sees himself as calm and confident off the pitch, and driven and determined on it.
"I am a calm and chilled guy out of the pitch but on the pitch I change completely, determined, focussed," he said upon signing for United.
"When I don't really know (people) I am quite quiet but when I get to know everyone I like to make jokes and banter."
Another of his hobbies is chess. "I was playing a little bit when I was younger and suddenly two or three years ago I wanted to play and I really enjoyed it," he said.
"I play online, I have a chessboard at home but no one to play against!"

Mbeumo grew up in a small town in France, his first football shirt was a United one with Ronaldo on the back and his dream was to become a footballer. To do so for United would have felt a long way off, but it's one he has now realised.
"As soon as I knew there was a chance to join Manchester United, I had to take the opportunity to sign for the club of my dreams," said Mbeumo.
"This is a massive club, with an incredible stadium and amazing fans, we are all really determined to challenge for the biggest trophies."
That is music to the ears of Amorim and the United fans, so too is Mbeumo's piano playing.

headline: LUCKHURST: Manchester United are the biggest winners in Marcus Rashford deal after Barcelona changed their mind
body: Back in January, the word from Barcelona was that the club’s sporting director, Deco, was “not that fussed” about Marcus Rashford.
Rashford ended up playing in a different shade of claret and blue at Aston Villa, underwhelmed and has now ended up at Barcelona.

It is a move that does not make much sense yet also makes sense. Barcelona have a deluxe back-up to a front three of Raphinha, Lamine Yamal and Robert Lewandowski. Manchester United have found a club prepared to cover Rashford’s £325,000-a-week salary. It was always going to be a loan with an option to buy.

Barca have admired Rashford for several years yet are signing him at one of his lowest ebbs. Villa declined the chance to buy him for £40million, Rashford had his squad number revoked and was ordered to report at United’s Carrington training complex after the first team had left this month.

An agency source said Rashford has “done extremely well” to get Barcelona. The Spanish agent, Arturo Canales, helped broker Rashford’s loan to Villa in February and was re-hired to specifically secure a move to Barcelona.

United have done extremely well to get Rashford off the books before August. Liverpool merit a mention. They resisted selling Luis Diaz to Barca after their prime target, Inaki Williams, signed a new contract with Athletic Bilbao. Rashford is Barca’s plan C and, on paper, a substitute for La Liga's champions. He has broken double figures in only one of the past four seasons for United.

High-ranking figures at United expected him to move abroad. Rashford mischievously refused to discount crossing the divide to Manchester City or heading down the East Lancs Road to Liverpool. There was no concrete evidence either of United’s rivals were interested in him.

It is in United’s interests that Rashford performs in Spain. It would make him more sellable next year, when he will have entered the final two years of his United contract. While Ruben Amorim is in situ, there is no chance of United reintegrating Rashford back into their first team squad.

Rashford has put in the hours over the summer. His Instagram account, almost certainly run by his brother and former agent, Dwaine, has charted a rigorous training schedule of gym-work and ball-work. Rashford spent four hours in a Salford gym last Monday.

Hangers-on weighed Rashford down in recent years but his entourage on holiday in Cannes were on the grass with him. He was joined by brothers Dwaine, Dane, cousin Lois and former United academy teammate Roshaun Williams.

Rashford shone at Camp Nou in United's engrossing 2-2 Europa League knockout draw in February 2023, scoring their equaliser and single-handedly forcing Jules Kounde's own goal. He was at his zenith that season, with the caveat that Rashford's form came with his camp in the midst of contract negotiations.
Have a glance at Rashford's goals tallies over the past four seasons: five, 30, eight and seven. You can pinpoint the one that preceded a lucrative salary hike.

Despite that 30-goal season, privately he bristled at some of Erik ten Hag's methods and how dogmatic the Dutchman could be. Their working relationship disintegrated during Ten Hag's final year at United.

Rashford was irritated to start the 2023-24 season up front while Rasmus Hojlund recovered from a stress fracture of the back. At Villa, Unai Emery regularly played Rashford through the middle. Lewandowski, 37, is not showing many signs of slowing down but he is out of contract at Barcelona next year.

After Amorim discounted Rashford from selection, the player exercised some moderate PR, attending a game in his hospitality box at Old Trafford. There was polite applause from the Stretford End on his final squad appearance when he warmed up against Newcastle in December.

Figures at United are continuing to tread on eggshells with Rashford, still keen to highlight his legacy as one of their most striking academy graduates. Rashford has long since abandoned diplomacy, thanking Alejandro Garnacho for his puerile post in a Villa 'Rashford 9' shirt last month.

One down, three to go for United. Jadon Sancho, Antony and Garnacho will, by hook or by crook, be gone by 7pm on September 1. United will then have a leaner, fresher and more harmonious forward line. One that has to be sharpened by a new striker.
They need to be fussed about that.

headline: RAILSTON: United must arrange four more exits after Marcus Rashford departure
body: "Yeah, for sure. Everybody in the world wants to play with the best. Hopefully... We'll see."
Those words came from Marcus Rashford last month when a Spanish influencer asked whether he would like to play with supremely talented Barcelona teenager Lamine Yamal.

Rashford has been fluttering his eyelashes at Barcelona, and he will realise his goal of playing for the Catalan club. Manchester United have agreed to send Rashford on loan for the 2025/2026 season and Barcelona will cover his entire wage packet throughout his stay at Camp Nou.

The 27-year-old was one of five players who were told to delay their returns to Carrington after each expressed a desire to leave. United have arranged Rashford's exit with favourable terms and now must address the futures of Alejandro Garnacho, Antony, Jadon Sancho, and Tyrell Malacia to offset incomings.

United have not sold Rashford on a permanent deal, but removing one of the highest earners from the books is a boost, and Barcelona are expected to trigger their option to sign him at the end of the season.

It feels inevitable Rashford will show enough for Barcelona to activate their option to sign him. He may well impress and pundits will then doubtless suggest United made a mistake by allowing him to leave.
The script with Rashford over the next 12 months at Barcelona is predictable, but it will be a surprise if he can sustain strong performances across successive seasons in Spain.
United's attention now turns to the four other players on the naughty step. Garnacho retains the highest value and arranging his sale will unlock much-needed funds for Ruben Amorim.
An initial £127.5million has been splashed on Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo, so selling Garnacho is now at the top of the transfer agenda.
Chelsea and Napoli were interested during the January transfer window. The winger's agent attended a game at Stamford Bridge and told the world he was there by posting on social media.

The suggestion is that Garnacho would prefer to remain in the Premier League, but United will try to offload him to the highest bidder because. They should be trying to get £50million-plus for a player who has proven himself in the Premier League and still has considerable upside. The only problem is potential suitors know Amorim wants rid.
Antony deserves credit for creating a market for himself. The Brazilian was utterly hopeless in Manchester but looked a completely new player during his loan with Real Betis last season.
If you pretend his £86m transfer to United never happened, Antony would look like a decent prospect and a permanent move to a European club is on the cards for him this summer.
United must sell Antony for £32.8m to avoid making a PSR loss. The club will also look to negotiate a permanent deal for Jadon Sancho and the Italian press claim Juventus are advancing.

Juventus will be asked to cough up a fee for Sancho, although United will get peanuts from the last player of the out-of-favour-five, Tyrell Malacia, who looked unconvincing during his PSV loan last term.

The nightmare scenario was that all five players would still be at Old Trafford near the end of the window, but United have shifted Rashford and it's hoped the floodgates will now open for the other exits.

headline: Ruben Amorim has four games to decide on a new Manchester United partnership
body: One down, four to go. Manchester United kicked off their pre-season schedule with a 0-0 draw against Leeds United in Stockholm on Saturday.

For those who watched from either inside the Strawberry Arena or on MUTV, it is unlikely it will be remembered very fondly. In typical pre-season fashion, the game was light on quality and highlights.

United will hope to serve up something a little bit better when they face West Ham United at the MetLife Stadium in New Jersey this weekend in their opening game of the Premier League Summer Series. The Reds fly out to the US on Tuesday and will spend the best part of a fortnight on the other side of the Atlantic.
Their pre-season tour will feature friendlies against Premier League counterparts West Ham, Bournemouth and Everton. Each game will represent an opportunity for head coach Ruben Amorim to experiment.

By the time United return to England and prepare for their final friendly of the summer - a clash with Fiorentina at Old Trafford on August 9 - Amorim will almost certainly have an idea in his mind of what his strongest starting XI looks like.
United face Arsenal in their Premier League at Old Trafford on August 17 and will be determined to hit the ground running after last season's struggles.

Although there is still just under a month to go until their Premier League curtain-raiser, some places in Amorim's starting XI are already nailed down. The likes of Leny Yoro, Patrick Dorgu, Bruno Fernandes, Mathes Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo will all believe they are guaranteed starters.
Occupants of other positions within the XI remain to be decided, with United's four remaining friendlies set to dictate Amorim's thinking.

The Portuguese chief's decision to start Fernandes in the middle of midfield for the draw with Leeds felt particularly telling. Following the addition of Cunha, the feeling throughout the summer has been that Fernandes will start the new campaign in midfield.

Cunha operated as the left-sided No.10 in Stockholm and Toby Collyer, much to everyone's surprise, started as the right-sided No.10. Mbemo and Amad will be the leading contenders to occupy that role come mid-August.

Casemiro and Fernandes started alongside each other in midfield in Stockholm before Kobbie Mainoo and Manuel Ugarte were partnered together for the second half. United were better after the break and Mainoo was a bright spark.
Amorim struggled to determine Mainoo's best position last season, tasking him as either a No.8 or as one of the playmakers. On Saturday's evidence, Mainoo looks more than comfortable in midfield.

However, he was playing alongside Ugarte, who is a defensive specialist, meaning the England international had the freedom to get forward and be adventurous with the ball. If he starts the season next to Fernandes, he will not have that luxury amid the latter's hunger to attack.

To ensure United, who still want to sign a midfielder this summer, strike the right balance in the engine room, Ugarte and Fernandes look the best partnership on paper. Ugarte is an excellent ball-winner and his qualities compliment Fernandes.

Mainoo, though, will believe he has lost time to make up for after a stop-start 2024/25 campaign. However, the prospect of him and Fernandes working side-by-side could leave United vulnerable and potentially exposed in the middle.
Casemiro returned for pre-season looking leaner and fitter, meaning he will be refusing to give up hope of becoming a regular starter this season.
The three US friendlies and the clash with Fiorentina in M16 next month could settle this conundrum for Amorim.
Manchester United have launched their new away kit for the 2025/26 season, inspired by the club's early-1990s Adidas snowflake kit.

headline: Man United next transfer priority made clear amid Bryan Mbeumo verdict
body: United and Brentford eventually settled on a £71million total package, made up of a £65million initial fee and with £6million in performance-based add-ons. Mbeumo arrives in time to join the bulk of the club's pre-season training, and he could make his first appearance against West Ham in the Premier League Summer Series tour in the US this weekend.

Between Mbeumo and fellow summer signing, Matheus Cunha, United have poached two of the top-ten Premier League goal-scorers from last season. Addressing Ruben Amorim's misfiring attack was a key problem to solve in the summer transfer, and these two may well go some way to inspiring some fear in opposition defensive lines yet again if they can replicate anything like last season's form.

Some fans say that Mbeumo is their ticket back to Europe, after enduring one of the worst top-flight seasons in living memory. Reader LesJohnson says: "Cunha and Mbuemo are the first steps in the right direction. There is nothing much wrong with our goals against, and it was obvious to everybody we need to put away our chances, we created enough of them.

"I remember the West Ham game, we hammered them until the final third, then they popped a counterattack in the net. This will not happen now, of that I am sure. We can out-score most teams with these guys and that was our Achilles Heel last season, not scoring enough, only 44 in a season is inept as we all know.
"Compliment to our directors for getting these deals done and proving the doubters wrong. United will be back, maybe not at the very top, but teams will now start to fear us yet again."
Commenter Wazzaa writes: "With these new players (still need a No.9) and other players gone, you will see a big difference this season. Next season Amorim will be all of the doomsayers' hero..."

RociLal says that the club are on the right track: "Overpriced but on the bright side, both Cunha and Mbeumo are Premier League proven and of the right age at 26. Both these lads will definitely improve our attacking play. If we can get in a new goalkeeper, and an energetic midfielder to replace Casemiro, I'm confident United will challenge for a spot in the top-seven of the Premier League."
Tt84 writes: "If we do nothing else, I think this puts us in the Europa League next season.
"Goals conceded we were a top-seven team. Goals scored were 16th I think. Fix the goals scored and theoretically goals conceded should drop also. I think we are a top-seven team now."

There's still work to do in MickyFinn's mind: "Finally... we can move on from this saga. Now, let's see United go get a striker and a goalkeeper in, they need a midfielder, too, but I doubt they're going do that."
Have your say! How do you rate Manchester United's summer transfer window business so far? Comment below, and join in on the conversation.

headline: RAILSTON: Why Manchester United will not care about criticism of Bryan Mbeumo deal
body: After a month of negotiations, Manchester United have officially signed Bryan Mbeumo.
The transfer has been a long time coming and fans were relieved to see the announcement on Monday, which confirmed the £65million signing, with a further £6m potentially due in add-ons.
Mbeumo has signed a five-year contract with the option of another year, and the forward will travel to the United States on Tuesday with his new teammates for the pre-season tour.
It was important to complete a deal in time for Mbeumo to feature in the US and United got the transfer over the line in the end, despite discussions with Brentford dragging on.
Some fans were concerned when Mbeumo had not signed in time for the opening pre-season friendly against Leeds in Stockholm, but that game was essentially a training exercise.
It wouldn't have made much difference if Mbeumo had travelled to Sweden last weekend, although it was obvious why United wanted him to arrive ahead of their trip across the Atlantic.

The USA tour will provide Amorim with the opportunity to intensely work with his players across the next fortnight. The Reds boss will hope to lay the foundations for a successful campaign while in the States.
Mbeumo needed to be a part of that, partly because he needs to adapt and partly because discussions rumbling on for any longer could have forced United to finally walk away from the player.
United have received some flak for taking so long to sign Mbeumo. However, he will feature in America, which is a huge positive, and it was important that the structure of the deal was deemed fair.

Brentford will receive the fee they wanted from the start, but United did not surrender to their demands immediately, submitting two unsuccessful bids before a breakthrough, and negotiating a favourable deal structure.
The London club held the aces during talks. Mbeumo had entered the final year of his contract, but Brentford had the option of extending by 12-months, which helped their bargaining power.
The player indicated his desire to move to Manchester, though, which has been key during the transfer saga over the last month. He desperately wanted a summer switch to United.
The Cameroon international completed his medical over the weekend and was pictured in a suit at Carrington - appearances go a long way and Mbeumo has already made a good first impression.

Rival fans have questioned the transfer fee, but they only need to look at the market for home truths. Anthony Elanga (six goals) signed for Newcastle in a £50m deal, Chelsea signed Jamie Gittens (12 goals) from Borussia Dortmund for £51.5m and Noni Madueke (11 goals) signed for Arsenal for £48.5m.
Mbeumo scored 20 goals in the Premier League - his statistics weren't inflated by cup competitions - and also contributed eight assists, so the initial £65m fee seems like fair market value.
United will be delighted with Mbeumo's arrival and he should be a superb addition.

headline: LUCKHURST: Urgent business, briefing and counter briefing - how transfers affect a Man United manager's mood
body: "The third player is official yet?" Jose Mourinho asked the startled Manchester United press officer.

That was at Mourinho's introductory press conference in the old No.7 suite at Old Trafford nine years ago. United were scheduled to fly to Shanghai in less than a week and Mourinho was impatiently awaiting Henrikh Mkhitaryan's arrival. Mkhitaryan was in Manchester the following day and on the plane to China.

Supporters are not the only ones who revel in the fillip of a new addition in time for a pre-season tour. In 2015, Matteo Darmian, Bastian Schweinsteiger and Morgan Schneiderlin all signed over the weekend before United departed for Seattle and images of the newbies were predictably lapped up.

Romelu Lukaku was already in Los Angeles, holidaying with Paul Pogba, when United flew there for their buoyant 2017 tour. United had agreed a club record fee for Lukaku (rising to £90m) and had blindsided Chelsea to sign him from Everton. Such a move, after a Europa League triumph in May, maintained the feel-good factor.

That was in stark contrast to Mourinho's fraught final tour in 2018, overshadowed by briefing and counter-briefing. After congratulating his daughter, Matilde, on her graduation, Mourinho's first words at his opening press conference at the UCLA were "our pre-season is very bad".

He publicly demanded two more signings and never got them. Ed Woodward dodged Mourinho across four different states and was eventually spotted hurriedly catching up with him in the bowels of the Hard Rock Stadium in Miami. Woodward looked like he was caught between a rock and a hard place.

One of the senior United players in Los Angeles was hesitant about a media activity due to the manager's "bad mood". It did not improve in Phoenix, Ann Arbor or Florida and Woodward questioned a prospective employee on how to deal with Mourinho's outbursts.

Woodward never truly recovered from his first summer as executive vice-chairman in 2013. He breezily briefed that he had left the tour in Australia on "urgent transfer business". Cesc Fabregas was leading him down the garden path.

The high point of David Moyes's reign came at the start when he got his hands on the Community Shield. His mood afterwards was tetchy as reporters grilled him on the Fabregas collapse. Moyes accused some of writing "untruths". Moyes was already unravelling after an exhausting pre-season in Australia, Japan and Hong Kong.

2018 was the last tour where a United manager did not agree to the traditional sit-down with the travelling British journalists. Mourinho felt he was lacking allies and he derided a member of the communications department's suggestion on how to counter the criticism.

Ruben Amorim's tan suggests he has enjoyed plenty of sun during his downtime and his demeanour should be sunnier than his compatriot's seven years ago. United players are already buoyed by the breakthrough for Bryan Mbeumo, likely to be unveiled before they touch down in Chicago on Tuesday.

Having Mbeumo and Matheus Cunha on the plane and, hopefully, on the MetLife pitch against West Ham United next Saturday will change the perception of a team that has recorded a minus goal difference in successive seasons.

Amorim did not speak to the travelling journalists in Stockholm on Saturday but is scheduled to address the press in Chicago on Friday. The line of questioning will not be as intense with two £130m forwards added to a blunt attack.

United are close to a settled XI: Leny Yoro and Matthijs de Ligt were among the first recruits of the Ineos era, Harry Maguire had his contract extended in the New Year, Patrick Dorgu and Manuel Ugarte arrived within the last 12 months, Bruno Fernandes committed through a new contract last year and the rejection of the Saudi Pro League this, while Amad was also tied down on new terms.
The issues are at the back and up front. United have prioritised their attack over the goalkeeper and the timing of Andre Onana's injury could work in his favour ahead of the September 1 deadline.

The more pressing matter is the striker. With Joshua Zirkzee back in Manchester nursing a minor injury, Rasmus Hojlund did not even start against Leeds United. Amorim picked a rotational XI that was demonstrably not the strongest available to him, with two auxiliary centre backs in the back three and rookie Diego Leon in from the start.

Yet there was possibly something to read into Chido Obi's inclusion. His performance and goals in the post-season tour win in Hong Kong did him no harm. Hojlund's form that night was identical to his competitive outings and he does not have the confidence of the United manager or supporters.
But Obi cannot lead the line for United in four weeks' time. By the time Arsenal's coach pulls into Old Trafford, United best have made that third player official.

headline: Full confirmed list of Man United ins and outs for summer transfer window as latest signing confirmed
body: Bryan Mbeumo is the latest new face through the door at Manchester United after the club confirmed his arrival from Brentford.

United saw two bids rejected for the Cameroon international before an agreement was reached. Mbeumo has signed a five-year deal with the option of an additional year, with United paying £65million plus a possible £6m in add-ons. He joins Matheus Cunha, Diego Leon and Enzo Kana-Biyik on the list of new arrivals.

‌More new signings are expected to be made and there will also be plenty of departures. Alejandro Garnacho, Jadon Sancho, Antony and Tyrell Malacia have all told the club of their desire to explore opportunities away from Old Trafford. Marcus Rashford also wants to leave United and he is set to join Barcelona on a season-long loan deal.

A whole host of departures have already been confirmed this summer, with Victor Lindelof and Christian Eriksen both leaving the club after their contracts expired. Jonny Evans has retired but he has been appointed head of loans and pathways and so will remain at United.
In: Matheus Cunha (£62.5m - Wolves), Diego Leon (£3.3m, rising to £7m with add-ons), Enzo Kana-Biyik (free transfer - loaned out to Lausanne-Sport), Bryan Mbeumo (£65m).

Out: Victor Lindelof (end of contract), Jonny Evans (end of contract, appointed head of loans and pathways), Christian Eriksen (end of contract), Hubert Graczyk (end of contract), Tom Myles (end of contract), Tom Wooster (end of contract), Sam Murray (Carlisle United, free), Jack Kingdon (end of contract), James Nolan (end of contract), Dan Gore (Rotherham, loan), Sonny Aljofree (Notts County, loan), Joe Hugill (Barnet, loan), Habeeb Ogunneye (Newport County, loan).

headline: Best available centre-backs: Liverpool-linked Premier League star top, Arsenal man seventh
body: Including a Liverpool transfer target and Arsenal defender Jakub Kiwior, here are the 10 best centre-backs available to sign this summer.
We also have the best available strikers, attacking midfielders, wingers, and defensive midfielders.

10) Mario Gila (Lazio)
A player going under the radar in Serie A is Lazio defender Gila. The uncapped Spaniard turns 25 in August and is under contract at the Stadio Olimpico until 2027, so there is likely some degree of willingness to sell this summer.
Lazio picked him up from Real Madrid for around £5million in July 2022, and he’s gone on to play 84 times for the Italian giants, scoring two goals.
Comfortable and confident on the ball, Gila is an astute defender and would be a top signing for any big club looking to bolster their defence.

9) Ousmane Diomande (Sporting)
The Ivorian has previously been linked with Arsenal, Manchester City, Manchester United and Tottenham, but FA Cup winners Crystal Palace seem the most likely, even if that rumour has gone very quiet.

Jarell Quansah’s move from Liverpool to Bayer Leverkusen hasn’t quite triggered a transfer domino effect in the Premier League, though the Premier League champions have ramped up their pursuit of Palace captain Marc Guehi. No bid has been made or seems close, but if he leaves the Eagles, Oliver Glasner must get his replacement right. Diomande would be a coup and a safe option in that regard.
READ: Palace should be ‘genuinely astounded’ by Arsenal, Liverpool part-exchange offers for Eze and Guehi

8) Giorgio Scalvini (Atalanta)
There are question marks over two things: Scalvini’s availability and Scalvini’s injury record. One report from Italy says he is ‘unsellable’, but Fabrizio Romano claims Newcastle United want him and ‘more clubs are keen’, with Atalanta receiving ‘initial approaches’. That certainly sounds like he’s ‘sellable’ — but only for big, big money.

The 21-year-old tore his ACL last June and was restricted to a mere eight appearances across all competitions in 2024/25, starting five times. After recovering from the serious knee injury, the young Italian was eased back in before suffering a shoulder injury in December, missing two games. He then injured the same shoulder in January and didn’t feature again for the rest of the season. That’s 42 games missed for Atalanta since the ACL injury 13 months ago.
The potential is still there, but you can understand the reluctance to break the bank. If he wasn’t so unlucky with injuries, he’d be a lot higher here.

7) Jakub Kiwior (Arsenal)
After a season-ending injury to Gabriel Magalhaes on April Fool’s Day, Kiwior came into the Arsenal starting XI and did pretty well, staking a claim for a big-money transfer this summer – or more minutes for the Gunners in the Premier League.

Knowing Arsenal, they’ll struggle to get £30m, but really ought to be demanding closer to £45m, especially if the aforementioned Quansah cost Leverkusen £35m. The fact Kiwior is left-footed surely adds £10m to his value too. Apparently, that’s the world we live in now.

6) Antonio Silva (Benfica)
Chelsea and Manchester United are among the clubs to be linked with the Benfica defender, who apparently “wants Juventus”, per his agent Jorge Mendes.

Benfica are known to be difficult negotiators, and talks over Silva will likely be no exception. He’s expected to be the next big-money sale after ex-Red Devils youngster Alvaro Carreras joined Real Madrid earlier this summer.
Still only 21, Silva has played 140 times for Benfica. Extraordinary stuff.

👉 Xhaka next? The most stunning transfer coups made by newly-promoted Premier League clubs

5) Goncalo Inacio (Sporting)
There’s a £51m release clause in Inacio’s Sporting contract and Manchester United have been linked for a while – long before Ruben Amorim left the Portuguese club for Old Trafford. Amorim would surely push for his signing, but United are prioritising other positions and don’t have the financial flexibility to go big on a centre-back.

Separating Inacio, Silva and Diomande wasn’t easy. I don’t watch Portuguese football too often…for my sins. But you don’t need to watch Sporting every week to know this boy is very good. With United surely out of the picture, it’s unclear where Inacio will end up. Maybe Liverpool will get involved if they can’t lure Guehi away from Selhurst Park.

4) Loic Bade (Sevilla)
There is some bias here, believe it or not. Bade was identified by yours truly as a centre-back for the future when he was playing in Ligue 2 with Le Havre, so it’s absolutely imperative that he gets a big transfer and becomes recognised as one of the best defenders in Europe.

Bade did get a decent move to Rennes for £15m when he was 21, but it didn’t really happen for him there. Then came the bizarre Nottingham Forest loan that lasted four months and produced zero appearances. He’s found a home in Seville, though, and has been impressing for them since joining in January 2023, straight after leaving Forest.

The French international helped Sevilla win the Europa League in his first six months and signed permanently for around £10m. He’s been a top signing and is ready for a proper crack at the Premier League.

3) Carlos Lukeba (RB Leipzig)
Real Madrid are one of the clubs being linked with the 22-year-old, which does a lot of the talking for us, really.
There are high hopes for Lukeba, who hopefully doesn’t follow in the footsteps of another French Leipzig defender, Mohamed Simakan, by moving to Saudi Arabia.

Newcastle clearly want a new centre-back but could be put off by Lukeba’s left-footedness, with a long-term Sven Botman partner the priority, though the Dutchman has proved to be very injury-prone. Liverpool could emerge as a very serious option with another French ex-Leipzig defender, Ibrahima Konate, being fiercely linked with Real Madrid.
He has a €90m (£77.5m) release clause, which surely won’t be triggered this summer. It’ll be interesting to see Leipzig’s stance if offers come in, especially with Benjamin Sesko likely to stay.

2) Edmond Tapsoba (Bayer Leverkusen)
On a list full of children, Tapsoba stands out as an old fogey, aged 26. There are younger options, but there aren’t many better. Plus he has the benefit of entering his prime years having proven himself in a wonderful team.
The Burkina Faso defender played 46 times for Leverkusen in 2023/24, when they lost just once all season, in the Europa League final against Atalanta.

He featured nine times in the Champions League and is clearly good enough to make the step up, if he so desires. Leverkusen are still a very good side, even without Florian Wirtz and Jeremie Frimpong; we wouldn’t blame him for staying.
Transfer speculation has significantly died down, but all it takes is one Fabrizio Romano post on X, folks, and then every club is interested.

1) Marc Guehi (Crystal Palace)
You can argue about Guehi’s ‘availability’, but with a year left on his contract and interest from Premier League champions Liverpool, Crystal Palace should be open to selling their captain for the right price. Losing him on a free would be disastrous in the eyes of many, though there is a case for keeping him ahead of a Europa Conference League campaign. Is an extra year worth more than a potential £50m transfer fee?
There’s no real competition for Guehi here, in my opinion. He’s absolutely brilliant. He’s the future of England’s defence and deserves to be playing for a Champions League club.

headline: Transfer rumour ranking: Spurs eye Man Utd star, Real bait City by offering Liverpool target
body: Liverpool are linked with a Villa defender and a Real Madrid star who could be lumped into a package deal to lure away Manchester City’s captain…
With so much transfer talk doing the rounds, we’re here through the summer to sift through the bullsh*t and highlight the whispers that might have some substance.
Each day we’re ranking the top 20 rumours involving Premier League clubs, the higher the link, the more likely we feel they are to become done deals.
So we start with the tittle-tattle…

20) Rodri – Man City to Real Madrid
We’re told that Real are offering Eduardo Camavinga, Rodrygo and €40million for Rodri. Real probably value that package at around £170million. Which feels like a lot for a player coming off the back of a serious knee injury. But probably still not enough for City to seriously consider.

19) 🆕 Ezri Konsa – Aston Villa to Liverpool
A report in Spain suggests Liverpool could alter their focus to the ‘slightly more affordable’ Konsa since Palace are looking for £50million to sell Marc Guehi a year before he goes for free. Konsa is under contract until 2028 – would Villa demand less for him than what Palace are demanding for Guehi? We think not.

18) 🆕 Rodrygo – Real Madrid to Liverpool
The story goes that Liverpool are monitoring Rodrygo if Luis Diaz leaves. The Reds are insisting on top whack for Diaz, who is set to be the subject of an improved offer from Bayern. Real too were looking for around £86million for Rodrygo but they have since accepted they may have to settle for less. In that context, it makes sense but still somehow doesn’t pass the sniff test.

17) 🆕 Kobbie Mainoo – Manchester United to Tottenham
Spurs have made an enquiry to United over Mainoo, whose contract talks with his boyhood club are not progressing as quickly as either side might hope. That shouldn’t prompt panic, though, since the midfielder’s current terms expire in 2027 and United have the option to go for another 12 months beyond that. Still, does Mainoo fit Ruben Amorim’s system? He might be their best chance of getting some decent money in this summer.

16) Nicolas Jackson – Chelsea to Manchester United
United continue to be linked with Jackson but we hear that Chelsea have valued him at between £80million and £100million. If you’re not going to take it seriously, lads. We could see this happening, probably late and something exchange-y involving Alejandro Garnacho. But not if Chelsea keep pretending they want the silliest of money.

15) 🆕 Alejandro Garnacho – Manchester United to Aston Villa
Garnacho is being linked with Chelsea and Spurs but the noise seems to be building around Villa. Morgan Rogers to Chelsea, then Garnacho to Villa? The Villans would turn a profit from any such dealing and if they sit tight, they could get Garnacho for even less than the current asking price of around £40million. If they are really clever, they could probably get him on loan.

14) 🔼 Alexander Isak – Newcastle to Liverpool
It seemed as though Liverpool were taking Newcastle seriously when they were told that Isak isn’t for sale. And the intent the Reds are showing around Ekitike instead doused our initial suspicion that Dicky Hughes wasn’t done with Isak. But it all seemed a bit weird on Saturday when Isak was sent home from Glasgow ‘due to the speculation around him’ and Eddie Howe sounded less convincing that the Swede would remain with Newcastle beyond the end of the window. Maybe this one isn’t done?

13) Xavi Simons – RB Leipzig to Chelsea
A Chelsea move appeals to Simons and the Blues are keen to make it happen. But first they need to raise some cash and even then, they will look for a discount on the £56million RB Leipzig are demanding.

12) 🔽 Granit Xhaka – Bayer Leverkusen to Sunderland
It was thought Xhaka might be heading for the riches of Saudi but instead he fancies the splendour of Sunderland. Indeed, the ex-Arsenal midfielder has told Leverkusen he only wants to move to the Stadium of Light while urging the German club to do a deal quickly. Those pleas, though, appear to have fallen on deaf ears, with Erik ten Hag insisting Leverkusen have already lost too many key players this summer.

11) Joao Palhinha – Bayern Munich to Tottenham’
Spurs are looking for a new no.6 and while Conor Gallagher has been mentioned, there is greater clamour around Palhinha, who has been told he can leave Bayern after one season. Bayern want £30million; Spurs are chasing a discount. If they get one, and Palhinha still has some of the Fulham magic left, it would be a snip.

10) Eberechi Eze – Crystal Palace to Arsenal
Eze is keen on the prospect of moving to the Emirates and some reports suggest a deal is now down to the finer details of how the fee to activate his release clause is paid. Arsenal are a little tied up this week with Madueke and Gyokeres, but once those deals are done, we can expect some progress over Eze.

9) Yoanne Wissa – Brentford to Newcastle
Newcastle are having a ‘mare of a summer, but some rare good news came in the form of Wissa’s desire to move to St James’ Park. Only problem now is they need to deal with Brentford, who have already lost one forward to Manchester United. Given the Bees know Newcastle were prepared to spend big on Hugo Ekitike or Joao Pedro, the Magpies can expect a rough ride. They will have to try a lot harder than £25million.

8) Luis Diaz – Liverpool to Bayern Munich
Bayern made their move for Diaz, who wants to make a move of his own. But Liverpool wouldn’t entertain the bid of £58.6million, with the Reds insisting they want to keep the Colombian, though £87million might twist their arm. There seems to be an openness from all sides to a deal, with Diaz keen to make it happen. Bayern will return with an improved offer but the player may have to do his bit too since Liverpool are insistent on doing it their way.

7) Jadon Sancho – Manchester United to Juventus
It seems Juve have finally agreed a deal with Porto for Francisco Conceicao but the sales of Samuel Mbangula and Timothy Weah will allow the Old Lady to sign Sancho too. Agreements are said to be in place with both United and Sancho, who should be thanking his lucky stars even if he’s halving his salary. How will he cope?

6) James Trafford – Burnley to Manchester City
We all assumed Newcastle would pull their finger out after their initial bid of £27million inclusive of add-ons was rejected last month. Since then, though: nothing. Leaving City to swoop in for the England Under-21 keeper. Reports suggest City are trying to secure a discount on the £40million buy-back clause they hold for their ex-goalkeeper but with the increased noise around Ederson departing, it’s hard to envisage the Citizens allowing Newcastle back into the race.

5) Morgan Gibbs-White – Nottingham Forest to Tottenham
This one doesn’t seem to have moved in since Forest saw their arse over Spurs randomly plucking the same number out of the sky that appears on Gibbs-White contract under the buy-out clause. Forest threatened legal action and since then… nothing. The player is missing from Forest’s pre-season trip to Portugal but that’s to stay behind with his heavily pregnant partner. What now? For this to go through, Spurs must suss that they are legally on solid ground and pursue the deal at the cost of their original offer; or they sweeten the deal for Forest to sell a player who wants to move.

4) 🔼 Viktor Gyokeres – Sporting to Arsenal
After bemoaning the abject lack of progress in the last week, it seems we finally have some. Ornstein reckons Sporting and Arsenal are ‘on the verge of total agreement’. Which is where we thought they were but, apparently, a ‘conclusion is imminent’. Which is something we can all be thankful for.

3) 🔼 Marcus Rashford – Manchester United to Barcelona
Rashford is in Barcelona having secured the ‘dream’ move even he would struggle to argue that he deserves. A medical has been done and, all being well, Rashford will be doing kick-ups for the cameras on Wednesday.

2) Hugo Ekitike – Eintracht Frankfurt to Liverpool
Ekitike has landed in England – at least, he was scheduled to on Tuesday – for a medical and to sign his contract in London before immediately flying off again to join the rest of the Liverpool squad on tour.

1) 🔼 Cristhian Mosquera – Valencia to Arsenal
The delay between medical and confirmation is a pattern with Arsenal this summer but this one has really dragged. Mosquera is heading for Singapore to join his new team-mates but still we wait.

headline: Top 10 available defensive midfielders features potentially significant Man Utd sale
body: These 10 guys are the best defensive midfielders available to sign this summer. Only three Premier League players are on offer…
We also have the best available strikers, attacking midfielders, wingers, and central defenders.

10) Ardon Jashari (Club Brugge)
A transfer to AC Milan appears likely, though the Italian side has yet to agree a fee with Club Brugge for the 22-year-old midfielder. Jashari has made it clear that Milan is his preferred destination, but if negotiations with the Belgian club continue to stall, a move elsewhere can’t be ruled out. Given his stance, playing for Brugge again seems unlikely.

Since making his international debut in September 2022, Jashari has earned four caps and is expected to play a more significant role for his national team once Granit Xhaka retires from international football.

He’s a fantastic, young defensive midfielder with Champions League experience, having helped Brugge reach the last 16 of Europe’s premier competition last season. They lost to Aston Villa after an incredible 5-2 aggregate win over Europa League holders Atalanta in the play-off round.

9) Angelo Stiller (Stuttgart)
It’s unlikely that Stiller leaves Stuttgart this summer, but as a standout performer outside of the Champions League spotlight, he could be tempted by a bigger move.

The 24-year-old four-cap Germany international signed a new three-and-a-half-year contract in January, with Fabrizio Romano confirming that ‘several clubs’ wanted to sign him in the summer transfer window.
Valued at €45million (£39m) on Transfermarkt, Stiller played 47 times across all competitions last season, assisting an impressive 11 times from defensive midfield.

8) Douglas Luiz (Juventus)
The former Aston Villa midfielder left England to ease Profit and Sustainability pressures last summer. He had been superb in 2023/24, but his debut season in Italy was anything but.

Injuries kept him in and out of the Juventus squad and, when fit, he failed to make himself undroppable. Consistency eluded him, in part due to a lack of rhythm, and he never really got going. We all know what Luiz is capable of, and there’s rumoured interest from the Premier League. Based on his Villa form, £30million – his reported asking price – could be a snip.

7) Alan Varela (Porto)
Varela is only 24 but still uncapped for Argentina, which is mildly baffling. He’s quietly become one of the best defensive midfielders in Portugal, and we expected more concrete interest from the continent by now.

AC Milan, Atletico Madrid, Manchester United, Liverpool and Manchester City have all been linked, but Porto aren’t in the mood to do business on the cheap, especially after tying him down to a five-year contract in May.
That alone makes him pretty unlikely to move this summer.

6) Joao Palhinha (Bayern Munich)
One of the best defensive midfielders in the Premier League during his Fulham days, it just hasn’t happened for Palhinha at Bayern. He earned a deserved move last summer, but could be out the door again after just one season.

Fulham didn’t suffer without him and Palhinha barely featured for Bayern, starting just nine matches in all competitions and failing to hit 1,000 minutes across the campaign. At 29, he might prefer to stick around at a club like Bayern, where he’s only an injury or two away (to other Bayern players, obviously) from regular minutes under Vincent Kompany.

5) Morten Hjulmand (Sporting)
Viktor Gyokeres is the headline-grabber at Sporting, on and off the pitch, having forced a transfer to Arsenal, but Hjulmand is catching plenty of admiring glances of his own.

The Danish international scored against England at Euro 2024, but it’s the rest of his game that’s got Europe’s elite taking notice. He’s now Sporting captain and, at 26, has the tools to become a world-class holding midfielder if he picks the right next step.

4) Kobbie Mainoo (Manchester United)
Sir Jim Ratcliffe may reluctantly sanction Mainoo’s sale this summer to fund a rebuild, but only for a suitably ridiculous fee. Chelsea have been linked, though they already have more young midfielders than minutes to give them.

Mainoo was once untouchable at Old Trafford, but INEOS-era chaos has quickly changed that. It’s surprising that he hasn’t nailed down a role under Ruben Amorim – stylistically, he fits – but he’s not looked fully sharp this year.

A quiet summer involving a bit of Italian culture could be exactly what he needs. Clubs should be circling, because United might just let their most gifted academy graduate in decades leave for the right price.

3) Andrey Santos (Chelsea)
Expect to see a wave of Chelsea players spending time at Strasbourg, as Todd Boehly continues to treat the French club as his very own Vitesse.

Santos was one of the most impressive midfielders in Ligue 1 last season and was the only returning loanee Enzo Maresca included in Chelsea’s Club World Cup squad, with Strasbourg team-mate Djordje Petrovic missing out and eventually moving to Bournemouth.

Despite his huge ceiling, Chelsea seem happy to sell him to fund the next phase of their transfer binge, even if his replacement is worse and has less potential. Arsenal are reportedly sniffing around and need a bit more midfield depth following the exits of Jorginho and an unnamed Premier League footballer in his 30s.

2) Carlos Baleba (Brighton)
Brighton’s next mega-sale is likely to be Baleba, who’s quietly become one of the most complete young midfielders in the Premier League.

Clubs might not think he’s worth £80m, but Brighton think he is, and they’re rarely wrong. They won’t sell for a penny less, either. They’re not quite Benfica levels of shrewd, but they’ve set the standard in England.

1) Ederson (Atalanta)
There’s a good chance Ederson ends up in Saudi Arabia, with Al Hilal reportedly keen to sign him from Atalanta.
The Saudi Arabian side have struggled to convince their top targets to join this summer and consistent snubs mean his name is rising on their shortlist.

The 26-year-old often emerges as a Plan B for clubs chasing midfielders; Manchester City had him on standby if Tijjani Reijnders didn’t move, while United and Liverpool have been linked over the past year.
Mainoo is so much more than ‘pure profit’ and the very idea of selling him is an indictment of Premier League profit and sustainability rules.
Manchester United have suffered two of the greatest market value decreases of Premier League players this year, but one team owns four of the top ten.
Gary Neville insists he’s “pretty certain” that Marcus Rashford, Jadon Sancho, Antony and Alejandro Garnacho will all leave Man Utd this summer.
Amorim has made Mainoo a promise if he extends his Man Utd deal as the Red Devils ‘line up’ a £70m replacement for Bruno Fernandes.
Amorim has made up his mind and ‘the talk’ at Man Utd has now turned to where the midfielder might go and how much they can get for him.
Manchester United have been warned against making the “crazy same mistake” with Kobbie Mainoo after they were wrong to sell another player last year.

headline: Man Utd legacy tarnished as Rashford bags barely-deserved Barca move…
body: Even if the deal suits the immediate needs of all involved, the details of the agreement that takes Marcus Rashford from Manchester United to Barcelona reflect well on none of the signatories.

The two clubs are settling somewhat but Rashford, at least, has got what he really wanted and probably more than he deserves. In Catalonia right now, in between thanking his lucky stars, the 27-year-old is practising his keepie-uppies ahead of being officially unveiled as a Barca player.

None of this is how Rashford should be leaving United. If you were told a couple of years ago that the academy graduate would be swapping Old Trafford for the Nou Camp, the expectation might have been for Rashford to be revered and waved off with the warmest wishes of everyone at his boyhood club, while United banked a massive fee following a decade of stellar service.

Instead, after witnessing a couple of years of apathy, most Stretford End-ers will shrug wearily while Rashford becomes the chief beneficiary of Barca’s financial ineptitude that made their primary targets unattainable.

Doubtless, some of United’s online fanbase will be somewhat more animated. Many of Paul Pogba’s loons latched on to Rashford as the subject of their fanaticism and, to them, the player could no wrong. It’s always the manager at Manchester United.
The truth is, for the breakdown of the bond between Rashford and United, there is plenty of blame to go around.

Rashford can be excused a good deal of frustration over how his boyhood club was run for the most of the nine years since he burst into Louis van Gaal’s first-team. Too often in that time, he was one of the few certainties among the chaos and, as a local academy graduate, a throwback to the values United still claim to represent.
As recently as two years ago, Rashford looked set to cement a hero’s legacy at United when he became the first player in the post-Ferguson era to score 30 goals in a season.
Then he just seemed to get sick of it. All of it.

You would have to be an extreme optimist to view as a mere coincidence the peak of Rashford’s performance coming around contract renewal time. Almost as soon as the ink was dry on a £325,000-a-week deal, Rashford’s form and focus vanished – only to be rediscovered this summer when it became clear that Barca might be an option after all.

Perhaps only Rashford and those closest to him really understand what happened, but to many outsiders looking in, the love was gone. First for United, then football. Whatever might have been going on in his mind, he just looked thoroughly fed up with his lot.

On the pitch, even pretending to press became too much of a chore. In possession, the blinkers narrowed. Not as they tend to on the most ruthless of marksmen; whether he simply lost faith in those around him – not unimaginable at United – it became about self before side. And by 2023, his questionable decision-making was no longer limited to between the white lines.

👉 Rashford transfer ‘almost’ collapses but Manchester United ‘are the biggest winners’ of £25m loan

It was a human response. Here was a lad still rooted in his hometown, earning wealth for generations in his mid-20s, carrying more of the burden than many of his team-mates for United’s failings. Many would struggle with such expectation in that environment. Especially when factions of the right-wing press were still going after him for the heinous act of feeding children at a time of national crisis.

Rashford’s activism and advocacy, prompting more changes in government policy than any recent opposition party, should not be forgotten by a soul, least not anyone at United. They were more than happy to bathe in Rashford’s reflective glory. That pride should never fade.

Those things considered – plus more than one debilitating injury through which he played, and upheaval in his personal life – few among us are entitled to judge Rashford harshly for allowing his halo to slip. Perhaps we should give him more credit for the fact it didn’t happen sooner.

But since the back end of 2023, after signing his contract that summer, Rashford simply hasn’t seemed interested in rediscovering the form that earned that mega-deal. Even a pretence was too much. By the time Erik ten Hag was sacked, Rashford seemed to care not one jot how he was perceived by Ruben Amorim or anyone else at Old Trafford.

Amorim struggled to contain his befuddlement at the wider mess he inherited at United, but he saw no reason to sugar-coat the reality when it came to Rashford. “You can see on the bench we miss a bit of pace on the bench, but I would put [goalkeeper coach Jorge] Vital before a player who doesn’t give the maximum every day.”
That is damning. How bad must things have got with Rashford, since his partner in pre-derby crime, Alejandro Garnacho, continued to be used until Amorim could tolerate him no more?

Amorim’s keeper coach craic came towards the end of a run of a dozen games Rashford sat out amid a transfer request of sorts. Not a real transfer request, of course. Why go to the bother of writing a letter that will cost millions in needlessly-sacrificed salary when you can just use Henry Winter’s X account to tell the world you are ‘ready for a new challenge’ and still get paid?

The misguided belief among Rashford and his people seemed to be that he would have his pick of clubs in January. Barca were mentioned then; in terms of profile, AC Milan sounded a good match too. So perhaps it was slightly more humbling to find himself parked at Aston Villa rather than flying into a European giant.

Even there, Rashford was on the bench more than Unai Emery’s starting XI in the Premier League, and when given the choice to sign the temporary No.9 on a permanent basis, the Villans thought better of it.

All of which makes us wonder if this move to the actual FC Barcelona is a karmic consequence of all the child-feeding and Tory-bothering. Because, as Teddy Sheringham said, this is a grand opportunity that Rashford’s performances and mindset have not merited.

Maybe he should be careful what he wished for. Rashford’s ‘dream’ of signing for Barca could turn sour very quickly if the financially-illiterate club is unable to register him with La Liga. Until they juggle their finances to creep back under the league’s salary limit, it remains a very real possibility.
No-one back in his hometown wants Rashford thrust into that nightmare scenario, even if the stench of burnt bridges fills the Manchester air.

headline: Manchester United next? Eight teams who won the title from 15th or lower
body: Manchester United fans will be hoping the arrivals of Matheus Cunha and Bryan Mbeumo can be a catalyst for an Old Trafford revival after a dismal 2024/25 that ended with Ruben Amorim’s side firmly in the bottom half of the table.

Despite that, the Red Devils are still sixth favourites to become Premier League champions in 2026, but only eight sides have won the title after finishing 15th or lower the previous season since the inaugural top-flight campaign of 1888/89.

Everton – champions in 1914/15 from 15th in 1913/14
1914/15 was the final season of professional football before World War One saw the game suspended until 1919. Everton would hold on to the reigning champions tag for those five years, finishing one point above second-placed Oldham Athletic – the Latics’ highest ever position in the football pyramid. The previous campaign saw the Toffees escape relegation by just five points.

Manchester City – champions in 1967/68 from 15th in 1966/67
Before Sheikh Mansour’s billions propelled Manchester City to the top, the Citizens only had two league titles to their name. The first came in 1937, with the following season ending in the drop to give the club the unwanted distinction of becoming the only reigning champions to suffer relegation.

A second top-flight triumph came in 1968, when Joe Mercer and Malcolm Allison guided their side marginally clear of local rivals Manchester United a year after finishing 21 points behind the Red Devils.

Everton – champions in 1927/28 from 20th in 1926/27
1927/28 will always be remembered as the season Everton legend Dixie Dean scored a record-breaking 60 league goals. Unsurprisingly that seemingly unsurpassable feat secured the Toffees the title, one year after the club narrowly escaped relegation. Dean still managed to find the net 21 times even though his side ended the campaign just one spot clear of the drop zone.

Liverpool – champions in 1905/06 from 1st in Division 2 in 1904/05
Everton aren’t the only club on Merseyside that have defied the odds in a title race. Back in 1905 Liverpool became the first club to win the top flight straight after gaining promotion from the second tier. The Reds enjoyed a long spell in Division One from that point, not suffering another relegation until 1955.

Everton – champions in 1931/32 from 1st in Division 2 in 1930/31
Everton have some serious form for becoming champions a year after a lowly finish and their 1931/32 campaign tops the lot. Dean was the hero yet again, bagging 45 goals in the league after the Toffees came up as Division Two winners.

An embarrassing relegation to the second tier for the first time in the club’s history, just a couple of seasons after the 1928 title, was met by an incredible resurgence from the Goodison Park outfit.

Tottenham – champions in 1950/51 from 1st in Division 2 in 1949/50
Tottenham Hotspur’s first ever league title in 1951 came a season after the Lilywhites won the Second Division. Arthur Rowe’s men finished four points clear of Matt Busby’s Manchester United and featured future double-winning boss Bill Nicholson and a very famous right-back who would repeat the back-to-back-champions accomplishment as a manager.

Ipswich Town – champions in 1961/62 from 1st in Division 2 in 1960/61
That man is none other than England’s World Cup-winning mastermind Alf Ramsey, who led Ipswich Town to their first and only Division One title in 1962. Incredibly it was the Tractor Boys’ maiden campaign at the highest level, having played in the Third Division South just five years prior to topping the English football pyramid.

Nottingham Forest – champions in 1977/78 from 3rd in Division 2 in 1976/77
While Liverpool, Everton, Spurs and Ipswich all lifted the title a season after winning promotion, Nottingham Forest remain the only club to achieve that incredible feat without coming up as champions. Brian Clough’s side finished third in the second tier in 1977 but a year later an outstanding 26-game unbeaten streak saw them top Division One.
Two successful continental campaigns in the years that followed gave the club the unique distinction of having more European Cups than domestic league titles.

headline: Man Utd ‘close’ to next exit after Rashford as Juventus look to add £72m flop in double deal
body: Man Utd are ‘close’ to selling Jadon Sancho to Juventus this summer and the Italian giants have their eye on another Red Devils man, according to reports.

The Red Devils have made two major signings this summer in the form of Matheus Cunha from Wolves for £62.5m and Bryan Mbeumo for £71m from Brentford, while Paraguayan youngster Diego Leon has also joined from Cerro Porteno.

A number of players are set to be sold to raise funds for summer incomings with Sancho, Marcus Rashford, Tyrell Malacia, Antony and Alejandro Garnacho amongst the names reportedly on the transfer list at Old Trafford.
Man Utd academy graduate Rashford is now closing in on a transfer to Barcelona with the forward travelling to Spain in order to complete a loan with an option to buy.

Transfer expert Fabrizio Romano wrote on X on Monday: ‘Marcus Rashford, set for medical as new Barcelona player today authorized by Man United. All documents are being exchanged between the two clubs today.’
And now Sancho looks likely to be the next of the “bomb squad” out the door at Old Trafford with Juventus now closing in on a deal to sign the former Borussia Dortmund winger.
READ: Mediawatch: Manchester United ‘shock bid’ rejected but ‘boost’ makes £80m Jackson signing inevitable
And now transfer insider Graeme Bailey has told United In Focus that Juventus could look to sign Rasmus Hojlund as well Sancho this summer.
Bailey said: “Damien Comolli believes a deal for Jadon Sancho is close but one for Randal Kolo Muani isn’t – which has seen him ask about Rasmus Hojlund.

“This is an interesting option for both Hojlund and United – if this double deal came off it would get rid of one of the bomb squad and another player who they accept is not going to have a starting role next season.

“United have made it clear they want another striker this summer, whether Hojlund stayed or not. I am told the club as a whole believe a parting of the ways would be the ideal scenario, coupled with them landing their new number nine.”
Former Chelsea and Liverpool defender Glen Johnson will be pleased with the latest news after telling Sancho and Rashford that they needed to move abroad.

Johnson said earlier this month: “There looks to be quite a few Manchester United players who are not in Rúben Amorim’s plans and destined for a summer exit. Two of those are Jadon Sancho and Marcus Rashford.

“Both players spent last season on loan, Sancho tried at Chelsea, and Rashford had a brief stint at Aston Villa, but neither managed to fully rediscover their form or force a way back into United’s plans.

“Realistically, even though both these players clearly have ability, those loan spells haven’t worked. They can’t get into the United team and I doubt any of the Premier League big guns will be looking at them.

“Where these guys go is completely up to them. It all depends on how much motivation they’ve got left, what level they want to push themselves to, and which manager takes an interest in them. But, most likely, I can see a move abroad for both Sancho and Rashford.
“We’ve seen more and more English players making that move to other European leagues in recent years, and this might be the best and most likely path for them now.”

headline: Mbeumo has taken one of the biggest steps down in transfer history – but No.1 might never be beaten
body: Bryan Mbeumo and Mohammed Kudus have been openly desperate to take steps down to complete dream moves to Manchester United and Spurs this summer.

Kudus has climbed down the Premier League ladder to join Champions League side Spurs from West Ham, with Morgan Gibbs-White eager to jump even further down from Nottingham Forest if legal issues can be sorted.

He will hope to find himself among these, the biggest ever signings involving a player joining a club lower in the Premier League. But Mbeumo has jumped up to second after finally completing his Manchester United move.
N’Golo Kante – £32m in July 2016

From: Leicester (1st)
To: Chelsea (10th)

It is not often a player can leave the popular, newly-crowned miracle champions for a loathed mid-table team with barely an eyebrow raised or an unkind word spoken. But the combination of Kante’s inherent likeability and the Freaky Friday scenario Leicester and Chelsea found themselves locked in a decade ago led to one of the strangest yet most straightforward transfers imaginable.

Chelsea, at the start of their rebuild under Antonio Conte, faced basically no competition for very possibly the best player of the previous season, although Arsene Wenger inevitably fluttered his eyelashes and PSG sniffed around.

Eight players moved to Premier League teams for bigger fees than Chelsea paid Leicester for Kante in the same summer. Arsenal spent more on Granit Xhaka, Spurs invested as much on Moussa Sissoko and Manchester United paid about three times more for Paul Pogba. Phenomenal work from all involved.
Alex Iwobi – £34m in August 2019

From: Arsenal (5th)
To: Everton (8th)

Marco Silva kept a straight face when describing Iwobi as “one of our main targets”, despite the Toffees having to rush through a move in the final two hours of the 2019 transfer window after finally abandoning their summer-long pursuit of Wilfried Zaha.

Iwobi’s future was intrinsically linked to that of the Crystal Palace talisman either way. The Nigerian said he would have to consider leaving Arsenal if Zaha joined the Gunners due to the added “stress” of competing for places, with that pressure enough to evoke panic even when it was only Nicolas Pepe who moved to north London.
Everton had finished 16 points behind Arsenal but in the midst of a period of lavish spending reached up the table to make Iwobi the third-most expensive player in their history at the time.
The gap was actually closed to seven points in 2019/20, with Iwobi a late substitute in an abysmal game watched from the stands by incoming managers Mikel Arteta and Carlo Ancelotti.
Lewis Hall – £35m in July 2024

From: Chelsea (6th)
To: Newcastle (7th)

A slightly different case, Hall’s marriage with Newcastle was arranged when the Magpies were eight places higher than Chelsea, but by the time that loan was made permanent a year later the Blues were one position and three points ahead.

It is unknown whether or indeed how many of the £7m add-ons included in the deal have been triggered, but more than 50 appearances, an actual trophy and a couple of England caps might leave Champions League qualification as the only box left unticked.
Juan Mata – £37.1m in January 2014

From: Chelsea (3rd)
To: Manchester United (7th)
While Manchester United were officially Premier League champions for a little under four more soul-sapping months, their star had already fallen by the time Mata’s helicopter landed at Carrington.
David Moyes welcomed the Spaniard with unsurprisingly open arms, hoping he could galvanise his fading first season at Old Trafford as Manchester United sat seventh, a point clear of Newcastle.

Chelsea were third at the time the deal went through, much to the chagrin of Wenger. “Some teams have already played twice against one opponent and some others not. I think if you want to respect the fairness for everybody exactly the same, that should not happen.”
He would loan Kim Kallstrom later that month in protest.
Mata, on the other hand, will probably forever remain the top scorer of Ryan Giggs’ entire career as a club manager.

Nemanja Matic – £40m in July 2017
From: Chelsea (1st)
To: Manchester United (6th)

The first of a great many awkward midfield keys signed to unlock Paul Pogba, it was Matic who Jose Mourinho described as having “everything he wants in a footballer” in what was presumably intended as a compliment but is actually a damning indictment beyond about 2015.
Conte was furious and for once entirely justified as Chelsea used the funds to restock their cupboards with Tiemoue Bakayoko and Danny Drinkwater before Ross Barkley arrived in January.

The Blues fell to fifth in what amounted to a solid title defence considering their previous efforts, beating Manchester United in the FA Cup final after Mourinho secured his self-identified greatest achievement of finishing second to Manchester City and waiting patiently for the title to be reallocated years later.
Cole Palmer – £42.5m in September 2023

From: Manchester City (1st)
To: Chelsea (12th)

Enough steaming missiles have been launched at the walls of Stamford Bridge, Cobham and any other property Chelsea have sold to themselves over the years for some to stick. Yet Palmer is still probably the one unqualified success story for Clearlake’s recruitment strategy.

How wasteful it would have been had he heard Pep Guardiola out and decided to stay at Manchester City on the promise of a steady increase in minutes. Palmer felt he was already better than the 13 starts afforded to him in two seasons as a first-teamer and backed himself for a lead role elsewhere instead of playing a part in a supporting cast.
Chelsea provided that platform and their sole regret will be that Palmer’s contract only runs for another eight years.
Kyle Walker – £53m in July 2017

From: Spurs (2nd)
To: Manchester City (3rd)
The game went in the summer of 2017 and Walker was held responsible by many.

The mere concept of a full-back being sold for upwards of £50m caused a thousand think-pieces about the sport’s spiralling finances, followed by weeks of introspection as everyone pondered what part they had played in this and how they could possibly have stopped it.
Kyle Walker. £50m. Entire heads fell off across the country.

Forgotten in the ensuing madness was the fact that Walker had ostensibly taken a step down. He helped Spurs claim the Put The Pressure On Cup, securing his place in the PFA Team of the Year in the process, before being dropped by Mauricio Pochettino for the FA Cup semi-final, a north London derby and a match with Manchester United. Those seven minutes in a 2-1 win at White Hart Lane in May 2017 happened to mark Walker’s last in a Spurs shirt.

The right-back joined Manchester City that summer – for £50m! – and immediately explained that he moved to a team which finished eight points behind Spurs and was knocked out in the last 16 of the Champions League in Pep Guardiola’s debut trophyless season “to go on and pick up silverware”.
Walker left the Etihad this summer with 17 winner’s medals in eight years. Listen, fair play.
Mohammed Kudus – £55m in July 2025

From: West Ham (14th)
To: Spurs (17th)
It is an unflattering reflection of both club and player that Kudus signed a West Ham contract containing an £80m release clause in summer 2023 and left for £25m less two years later.

There were flashes of something exceptional over those 80 Hammers appearances under three different managers, but that wonderful first season being shown tapes of Steven Pienaar by David Moyes had faded long before Spurs swooped.

Thomas Frank identified the Ghanaian as his priority signing, Kudus picked out Spurs as the only club he wished to join, West Ham swallowed their pride to fund much-needed squad improvements and Arne Slot looked on longingly.
But 14th to 17th is barely a step down in comparison to what Morgan Gibbs-White is about to do.
Bryan Mbeumo – £65m in July 2025

From: Brentford (10th)
To: Manchester United (15th)

There was indelible proof of Manchester United’s perennial transfer pull when what could have been a summer-long auction between a number of potential suitors was reduced to a staring contest between Ruben Amorim’s side and Brentford.

Both parties felt they got the best out of a deal which took about two months to construct between the rejected opening bid and accepted third offer, with the bad blood likely to drip into next season.
Manchester United brought Brentford to the table at £55m and left with Mbeumo in tow once the numbers surpassed £70m.

For a player only beaten in terms of combined goals and assists in the 2024/25 Premier League season by Mo Salah and Alexander Isak, they will be content to have at least weakened one of the mid-table sides they must overtake on their way back up the ladder.
Moises Caicedo – £115m in August 2023

From: Brighton (6th)
To: Chelsea (12th)

The Liverpool copium was remarkably strong when their ambitious midfield transfer overhaul was slightly undermined by the panicked £111m bid Chelsea duly hijacked with a £115m offer of their own shortly after.

Their frustration and consternation was broadly understandable. Chelsea had just finished in the bottom half under Frank Lampard in what was until recently an unthinkably embarrassing crash through the glass ceiling the Big Six clubs installed long ago; there are two Europa League finalists who would take 12th right now.
Liverpool were far from the peak of their powers, finishing fifth and suffering early exits from the three knockout competitions, but they had Jurgen Klopp and a clear plan moving forward.

That centered around the midfield and when Jude Bellingham proved one immutable Real Madrid truth, the money the Reds put aside was thrown in the general direction of Caicedo. Brighton, who ended the 2022/23 just a place behind Liverpool, were happy enough to watch the auction unfold and escalate.
Bryan Mbeumo and Noni Madueke have joined the increasing legion of players swapping Premier League clubs for at least £50m, with more deals to come.

headline: Man Utd ‘turn’ to ‘very real option’ after striker snub as ‘cabal of superstars’ to follow Rashford exit
body: Man Utd are turning to RB Leipzig striker Benjamin Sesko this summer as a ‘cabal of superstars’ are set to follow Marcus Rashford out of Old Trafford, according to reports.
The Red Devils have been on the lookout for a new striker this summer as Ruben Amorim wants a new goalscorer before the transfer window shuts.
Only four Premier League sides scored fewer goals than Man Utd last season with Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee taking a lot of criticism for their lack of contributions.
Hojlund and Zirkzee scored just seven Premier League goals between them last term and there have been rumours that one of them will be sold this summer.

Man Utd have made enquiries about a number of strikers, according to The Athletic‘s David Ornstein, including Hugo Ekitike and Viktor Gyokeres, who look to be joining Liverpool and Arsenal respectively.
And now Football Insider claim that Man Utd have ‘turned their attention to’ signing Sesko after he failed to join Arsenal earlier in the summer transfer window.

Man Utd ‘could make a sensational move’ for Sesko ‘after missing out on both Viktor Gyokeres and Victor Osimhen’ and the Slovenia international is ‘a very real option to lead the line at Old Trafford next season’.

Sources have told the website that ‘despite the financial burden of the winger’s wages being lifted, United still need to get rid of some of their big-name players not wanted by Ruben Amorim’.
It is understood that ‘Jadon Sancho, Alejandro Garnacho, and Antony still need to be sold before the Red Devils can dip back into the transfer market’.
After post-season rumours that Bruno Fernandes could leave Man Utd for Saudi Arabia or Spain, the Portugal international is now committed to the club next season.
And former Man Utd assistant manager Michael Carrick has hailed Fernandes for his attitude despite admitting the Portuguese midfielder “can overdo it sometimes”.

Carrick said on Rio Ferdinand’s YouTube channel: “Yeah, I like Bruno. I work with him, with Ole, and he’s fantastic. He’s got a real, he’s desperate to do well. He’s so keen to do well, and that’s a really positive thing. And then sometimes, you can overdo it sometimes as well, and it’s such a fine balance. But his attitude, he plays every game, he never misses training, and he’s there all the time.

“Puts himself out there, puts himself forward, and he’s been the main man, really, the talisman for some time. And when there’s moments or there’s something that’s needed, Bruno’s been the one to step up. I really enjoyed working with him when I did.

headline: Marcus Rashford already given first Barcelona demand as Man Utd castoff told to ‘significantly improve’
body: Marcus Rashford has been told he must “sacrifice himself for the team” and “significantly improve his defensive approach” ahead of a move to Barcelona.
After a summer of will he, won’t he, Rashford finally looks to be on the verge of his ‘dream’ move to the Camp Nou after the Spanish club failed in pursuits of Nico Williams and Luis Diaz.
But Barcelona’s willingness to go for their third option Rashford was only given the green light following a meeting between the player and manager Hansi Flick.
Barcelona-based newspaper Sport claim Flick met with the castoff winger last Thursday and explained what his role in the team would be.

‘The German manager was very clear and explained his role in the team. He had to earn a starting spot and, most importantly, he had to sacrifice himself for the team by significantly improving his defensive approach.’
Barcelona’s concerns are backed up by stats. On average per 90 minutes in the Premier League last season, Rashford made just 0.59 tackles and won only a third of the tackles he attempted.
